content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Much better than just Reverse mode, a bit tedious to write out all the colors but a good and fun puzzle nonetheless.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this because it has a real concept behind. It can be in the shortest as well as speed mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved after this was turned into non-reverse - I like the idea!
Statement added. Reverse mode is now removed. Only fastest and shortest modes are available.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The idea is not bad per se, but given the mode is meant to be reverse, this puzzle is probably just going to timeout on 7 out of 8 people, not only because of the hidden (and arbitrary) correlation between color and number, but also because the order of the colors doesn't have a "linear" effect on the result (e.g. first*1, second*10, third*100 etc.) as most of the other reverse puzzles have.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: People with knowledge in electronics have a huge advantage here. As a non-reverse I'd approve.
all but not reverse ! :D

This is a very interesting puzzle and I like it a lot - but I would say there is additional arguably unhelpful difficulty included in terms of the following: as it is currently set, based on what I could see in the IDE, the user would have to deliberately fail a few of the test runs just to be able to see what all 10 colours are and what the answers are meant to be to be able to map them to numbers. This could be resolved by either making sure all 10 colours are used in the examples section (currently only 4 are), and/or perhaps if instead of colours you used something like letters ABCDEFGHIJ, something in increasing order making it easier for the observer to come up with a mapping to numbers (in my example, A=0, J=9 - this way people might spot the pattern and know how to deal with all of the letters (which were previously colours). Apologies if more than 1 example will already be included in the statement section and my IDE experience is not relevant.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: More example has been added to understand the logic of the reverse.

The reverse can be solved without specific background knowledge.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: (I had already rejected, I don't understand why it is not mentioned.)
The reason is that this challenge seems to me impossible to guess.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Not suitable for reverse mode. Nearly impossible to figure out without prior knowledge about electronics. I could see it working as a regular clash, just not reverse mode.

Looks good, I found it fairly clear - 3 words mapping to 2 digits and some number of zeros, those words happen to be colours but could have been anything really and no need of electrical background - it's a simple code (by design!). Perhaps if the statement had mentioned something about the puzzle for the reviewers then that could have helped reduce rejects :-)

By the way, I don't see any approve/reject buttons, is it already closed or something?
Sorry, I'm new to the contributions part..

I tested it in the IDE.. Perhaps having more test examples in the explanation would be beneficial. I figured it out by looking at the test cases here, but if you have to run 'em all in the IDE, the time might not suffice.
Upvote! It seemed very difficult at first, but I was able to figure it out after a few minutes. Coding the solution is then quite trivial, very nice.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: too hard to guess

In this state it looks too difficult. Even if you know about this color coding, it's too difficult to guess without context.

I propose the same as @JBM

Multiple conversions per test case that give a better hint of the rules.

e.g. 
Test1:
Something confusing

Test2:
black black black 0
black brown black 1
black red  black 2
black orange black 3
...

Test 3:
black brown brown 10
black brown red 100
black brown orange 1000
...

and so on
Should probably go with massively more tests. (like: multiple conversions per case)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Impossible to guess.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I quickly saw how to get the output, but without knowledge of the code used, this is next-to impossible for reverse mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, perhaps a little time is needed to guess the puzzle.

But I don't know if it is so easy for someone that have no background in electronic.
I don't have a background in electronic, but I was able to solve it. I think it's a nice reverse clash
Done, I added a few more tests.
I agree, I added a few more tests.
ok, I updated test/validator 1 to have 2 more test cases to see.

It was rejected with "too hard to guess" comments without proposals of enhancements. So I put it in contributions in "WIP" mode and I modified test cases according to constructive remarks of lukasjapan and JBM. Approve/reject buttons will be available when I will switch to "Ready" mode.

I'm not quite sure why everyone fixates on the electronics aspect here.

It's a simple reverse. There's no need to understand its origin to guess its flow. It's a lot easier (more regular) than most of the reverse-only clashes out there.

It was modified with more test cases per test and is now considerably more easier (it's even very simple for some people). Have you at least noticed it or are you just too limited by rejecting just for reject without taking account of modifications ?
Example is updated, each color is present at least once now.
Good idea - it might be fairer to solve in the other modes.
Just want to add that if the game mode is changed, I think it is a very good puzzle indeed. Would approve in that case, barring an unclear description
It's now submitted with a statement and fastest/shortest modes only.

Oh! sorry, I don't see that test cases was changed.
I removed my rejection.

Even if you get it (I didn't get it at all in 15 minutes) you still need to determine 10 unknown magic variables. That's just too much complication for reverse mode. The fact there are even worse reverse mode clashes doesn't mean we should add more bad ones.
I agree with your reasoning. Just not with your assessment.
Alright! I'll be waiting : )
Nice, this should do. I already upvoted, but I'd like to approve the game. Is it the same thing? I don't see any approve/ reject button
